channel.title: Bypassing extreme internet censoring? (hypothetical!)
channel.description:
Let me just say, all of this is purely hypothetical, I'm not a conspiracy nut. I'm not planning on overthrowing my government and installing a new government either :3 It's important to a story in development by someone I know.
First of all, if a future totalitarian government wished to monitor and censor all internet traffic, and prohibit connection to foreign networks (of course the government itself would still be able to do that), how would it go about it?
My idea was some sort of replacement for the Internet Protocol that only allows you to connect to networks with a certain signature.
How would one then bypass such censoring? In other words, how would one connect to networks that [i]don't[/i] have a particular signature for example.
My idea on that was to use old hardware with old software (still using IPv4, for example) to connect to other networks or computers with the same protocols.
Which brings me to my final point: how would people communicate? There would only be a few servers using the old protocols still running (without the government's knowledge), so how would one easily find eachother, with standard present-day applications?
TL;DR: how do you use present-day household technology to circumvent a hypothetical future censored national (i.e. cut off from the rest of the world) internet, and would that 'national internet' work?
I hope someone can help me with this.

item.title: Bypassing extreme internet censoring? (hypothetical!)
item.dc:creator: Paddy
item.description:
Hahaha, at the people who think IPv4 is gone. IPv4 is still used pretty much everywhere. IPv6 is still years away from a global roll out, that being said, the US goverment did say people have to start using IPv6.

Same thing was said many years ago. Kiss your NAT, PAT class A, B and C addresses goodbye! Billions of IP addresses each, here we come!

Yeah, like thats gonna happen overnight. I bet 5 years down the line, IPv6 will only just be the dominant IP protocal.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing extreme internet censoring? (hypothetical!)
item.dc:creator: bur
item.description:
Level:

So, it’d be some system that only allows you to go through to certain sites you mean? Depends where the block exists. If it existed in your computers hardware or software, there would be modded cards or cracks made to circumvent the system. If it was at the ISP end or something, that’s a much more difficult system to get around, because all your traffic has to go through them. You could also use a proxy that just forwards the webpage you want to you but shows it as traffic from another site.

Yeah, it’d be the ISP. I’m not sure about the extent of censorship within the country, but the main thing is that there is no communication with the outside world.

The Minotaur:

A different method they might use is to not use the normal internet altogether, but perhaps create a “pirate internet” of sorts, similiar to pirate radio broadcasters. Maybe they could start using radiowaves of a frequency not monitored, or using a normal frequency, but encrypted. What I’m thinking of would be similiar to WiFi? Provided that I’m not mistaken on how WiFi works.

I’m looking for something more along these lines.
The idea is that someone finds some old computer that somehow escapes detection by the system blocking traffic with the outside world because the way it accesses internet is different from what it is then.

Wouldn’t it be possible to use the network infrastructure without using the standard protocols?

Let’s say for example there’s the Censored Internet Protocol (CIP) in the future. Couldn’t you then use the infrastructure with IPv4 (which is completely forgotten about by that time) and communicate with other people using IPv4?

The problem is that it’s supposed to be a coincidence, so there won’t be any elaborate schemes to circumvent the system involved.

The Minotaur:

If these are used in the book suggested, could you tell us the name of the book? It sounds like quite an interesting read.

I’m afraid this is very, very preliminary and isn’t by an established writer, so it will certainly not be published for many years.

Thanks for the links mattemuse.

Read full topic
